awd_titl_txt: Cretaceous Vertebrates from Madagascar: A Window into the Biogeographic and Plate Tectonic History of Gondwana
awd_abstract_narration:
Cretaceous Vertebrates from Madagascar: A Window into the Biogeographic and Plate Tectonic History of Gondwana

David Krause, Stoneybrook, EAR-1528273
Patrick O'Conner, Ohio University, EAR-1525915

This proposal is jointly funded by the Sedimentary Geology and Paleobiology Program (EAR/GEO) and the Africa, Near East & South Asia Program/Office of International Science and Engineering (OD).
 
ABSTRACT

Non-technical Explanation
The latter half of the Mesozoic Era witnessed profound changes in the configuration of landmasses that comprised the southern supercontinent Gondwana, with dramatic consequences for the associated vertebrate faunas. Madagascar lay near the center of Gondwana as it fragmented into its component parts. This proposal seeks to continue a project designed to discover and describe vertebrate fossils in a sequence of Cretaceous strata on the island, to analyze their paleobiology, to place them in phylogenetic and geologic context, and to employ them in testing biogeographic and plate tectonic hypotheses related to Gondwana as a whole and Madagascar in particular. PIs work in the Cretaceous of Madagascar is only at the very beginning of reaching its potential. To date, they have quintupled the previously known species diversity of Late Cretaceous vertebrates from the island and have discovered some of the most complete and spectacularly preserved specimens of Late Cretaceous vertebrates from the southern hemisphere and, indeed, the world. Many new taxa have been named and described. But much remains to be done in the vast expanses of paleontologically and geologically unexplored Cretaceous rocks of Madagascar. Many taxa are known by only fragmentary remains; many others are still to be discovered. With continued work, PIs are confident that Madagascar's Cretaceous vertebrate fauna will become one of the best known and best contextualized from the southern hemisphere and one of the primary standards against which other Gondwanan faunas of Cretaceous age are compared.

Technical Description
PIs propose to continue collecting terrestrial and freshwater vertebrate fossils of latest Cretaceous age from the Berivotra Study Area of the Mahajanga Basin of northwestern Madagascar, which continues to produce exquisite material of poorly known taxa and specimens of new taxa. Although they have published many detailed anatomical, functional, and phylogenetic analyses of taxa known from this basin, many more have been initiated and remain to be completed (in particular, on albuloid and amiid fishes, crocodyliforms, pterosaurs, sauropod and abelisauroid theropod dinosaurs, birds and other paravian theropods, and mammals). Some of this work will entail histological sampling, thus enabling a comparative analysis of ecosystem-scale, inter-element histological variation within single vertebrate skeletons and testing of hypotheses related to possible responses and growth history adaptations of taxa that are phylogenetically constrained, but which exhibit a wide array of morphological and functional specializations. 
PIs also propose to continue developing newly discovered field areas in the Mahajanga Basin, which are yielding new taxa of roughly the same age but from different paleoenvironmental settings. Finally, they propose to expand their efforts into the Morondava Basin of western Madagascar, where brief expeditions in 2010 and 2012 yielded important finds and demonstrated the potential for many more from strata older than those yielding fossils in the Mahajanga Basin. Discoveries from these earlier horizons will provide a deeper temporal context with which to address biogeographic and plate tectonic hypotheses. Indeed, PIs discoveries continue to have profound implications for the biogeographic history of the extant and extinct Malagasy fauna and for the relative importance of dispersal and vicariance during Gondwanan fragmentation. One of their overarching goals is to provide a key building block for reconstructing Gondwanan biogeographic history in the form of a temporally controlled, well-sampled vertebrate fauna from the Cretaceous of Madagascar analyzed in a rigorous phylogenetic framework, and within the context of accurate paleogeographic reconstructions. 
It remains a priority to conduct detailed stratigraphic, sedimentologic, and taphonomic studies of all sampled horizons in order to provide temporal control as well as paleoenvironmental and paleoclimatic context. More specifically, PIs propose to conduct: (1) a comprehensive analysis of Maevarano Formation taphonomy that will provide taxonomic summaries and maps for each major quarry, and will detail the preservation of the Maevarano Formation?s exceptionally-preserved vertebrate record; (2) a comprehensive report on the geochemistry and micromorphology of exceptionally-preserved paleosols and associated fluvial sediments in the Masorobe and Anembalemba members of the Maevarano Formation, which will provide critical insights into paleoclimate; (3) a study focused on trace fossils discovered in the Maevarano Formation, specifically back-filled burrows associated with an entombed carcass (subterranean scavenging); and (4) a study clarifying and formalizing the lithostratigraphy of Upper Cretaceous horizons in the Morondava Basin.

inst.inst_name: Denver Museum of Nature and Science
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE COLORADO MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Denver Museum of Nature and Science

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The Madagascar project, initiated in 1993, continued to be focused on the recovery, description, and analysis of the Late Cretaceous vertebrate fauna of Madagascar, along with associated geological data, in order to test hypotheses concerning the plate tectonic fragmentation of the southern supercontinent Gondwana and its effect on faunal evolution. It is conducted in collaboration with colleagues and students at the University of Antananarivo (Madagascar) and with substantial contributions from many other researchers around the world.

During the award period of grant EAR-1664432 (09/2016?08/31/2021), the primary tangible results of this project are in the form of 24 articles in peer-reviewed scientific journals and two book chapters. These publications cover a range of topics including putting on record three important new Late Cretaceous vertebrate taxa (the bird Falcatakely forsterae ? Image 1; the mammal Adalatherium hui ? Image 2; and the turtle Sahonachelys mailakavava ? Image 3); detailed documentation and comparative analysis of the anatomical structure of Adalatherium and the bird Rahonavis; phylogenetic analysis of Adalatherium and other Mesozoic mammals; analysis of ontogenetic changes, cranial morphology, and life history strategies in the non-avian theropod dinosaur Majungasaurus and the sauropod dinosaur Rapetosaurus; paleopathology in Majungasaurus; anatomical structure and functional morphology of the forelimb in Majungasaurus; documentation of the first postcranial remains in Gondwana of the largely Laurasian mammalian group Multituberculata; recording the presence of three taxa of elopomorph teleost fishes in the Late Cretaceous of Madagascar and their biogeographic significance; analysis and review of the biogeographic history of Gondwana in light of our discoveries in Madagascar; and documentation of Cretaceous sea-level changes along the western coast of Madagascar. Notably, this list includes three articles in the high-impact journals Science and Nature, an invited review of the Mesozoic biogeographic history of Gondwana in the Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences, and two monographic treatments, one a multi-chapter volume on the new gondwanatherian mammal Adalatherium hui and one on the previously named bird Rahonavis ostromi. It is also important to emphasize that anatomical and phylogenetic data sets have been uploaded onto MorphoSource, MorphoBank, Dryad, and/or journal-specific repositories for the benefit of other researchers. Also, during the tenure of EAR-1664432, we delivered 30 presentations at scientific conferences.

 

Broader Impacts

This project has served as a strong training ground for students and young professionals. During the reporting period, three students completed their Ph.D. dissertations, one student completed her Master?s thesis (and is currently finishing her Ph.D. dissertation under the guidance of project personnel), and three students completed their undergraduate senior honors theses on topics directly related to the project. In addition, five undergraduate students, six graduate students, and two postdoctoral associates were co-authors on papers resulting from the Madagascar project and eight undergraduate students, four graduate students, and two postdoctoral associates were co-authors on presentations at scientific conferences. Additionally, Madagascar vertebrate fossils have provided the large Denver Museum of Nature & Science (DMNS) volunteer and intern corps with highly valued informal education opportunities in fossil preparation, collections management, and public engagement.

In addition, the results of this project have been and will continue to be disseminated to the general public in a number of ways: print media, radio, television, and internet. Recent publications in Nature, Science, and Royal Society Open Science have received worldwide attention. As the most prominent example, our recent paper in Nature on the new gondwanatherian mammal Adalatherium, garnered >1.33 billion media "impressions" (as compiled by the public relations firm DKCNews).

Fossils that we have discovered from the Late Cretaceous of Madagascar, as well as replicas of them, have been or are currently exhibited in numerous museums and institutions of higher learning in the United States, but also in Canada, Europe, Japan, Korea, and Madagascar (34 at last count), with continuing requests for more. Exhibit focus on the Madagascar project since 2016 has been a priority at the DMNS, which welcomed 2.3 million visitors in pre-COVID 2019 alone. For example, casts and original specimens of Late Cretaceous Madagascan non-avian theropod dinosaurs, sauropod dinosaurs, crocodyliforms, and birds were a centerpiece in the ?Ultimate Dinosaurs? temporary exhibit (10/2017?1/2018), a pop-up exhibit (?The Crazy Beast of Madagascar?) was developed on the discovery of Adalatherium (6/2020?1/2021), and a display case dedicated to Madagascar fossils has been part of the Prehistoric Journey permanent exhibit since 10/2017. In addition to formal exhibits, Madagascar fossils have been frequently featured in our public-facing, open-view main fossil preparation laboratory and on several Madagascar-related museum webpages, and are used for special events at the DMNS such as Members Nights, Museum Free Days, Museum Summer Camp, Educator Open House, Earth Day, and Collections tours.

Finally, during the award period, we have presented approximately 100 public lectures on our work in Madagascar at various museums, universities, and colleges, as well as to natural history, civic, and school groups.

 


Last Modified: 11/14/2021
Modified by: David W Krause

Images (1 of )
  • Exquisitely preserved cranium and reconstruction of the bird Falcatekely forsterae from the Late Cretaceous of Madagascar, published in the journal Nature (OConnor et al., 2020).
    J. Groenke, P. O'Connor, M. Witton
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    David W Krause
    Falcatakely forsterae
  • Complete, well-preserved skull and skeleton and reconstructions of the gondwanatherian mammal Adalatherium hui from the Late Cretaceous of Madagascar published in a the journal Nature by Krause et al. (2019) and as a Society of Vertebrate Paleontology Memoir edited by Krause and Hoffmann (2020).
    A. Atuchin, S. Hartman, M. Stenzel, and Triebold Paleontology
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    David W Krause
    Adalatherium hui
  • Virtually complete skull and skeleton and reconstruction of the turtle Sahonachelys mailakavava from the Late Cretaceous of Madagascar published in the journal Royal Society Open Science by Joyce et al. (2021).
    R. Wicker, A. Atuchin
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    David W Krause
    Sahonachelys mailakavava
